body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Is 'having one choice to choose' the same as 'having no choice to choose'?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is a sum of an "},{"type":"text","text":"arithmetic progression","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} S & = 1+2+3+...+100 \\ & = \sum_{k=1}^n k & \small \color{#3D99F6}{n=100} \\ & = \frac {n(n+1)}2 \\ & = \frac {100(100+1)}2 \\ & = 5050 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The last digit of the sum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"very easy ,
by using formula  n(n+1)/2
(100*101)/2
=10100/2
=5050
and the last digit is 0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i used the formula of sum of n terms of A.P.
\frac{n}{2}*{2a+(n-1)d} "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
where n= total number of terms(here n=100)
             a=1st term of the series(here a=1)
             d=common difference between 2 consecutive terms(here d=1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Putting all the values in the formula we get-
\frac{100}{2}"},{"type":"text","text":"{2","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"1+(100-1)1} =5050"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" positive integers is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"T_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Substitute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=1000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"T_n = 500\times 1001 = 500500."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
The formula can be proven by induction quite easily, or with A.P. formula. There are also formulae for the sum of squares, cubes, fourth powers, and so forth, but they grow in complexity."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Alternatively, you could use a method Gauss is said to have used as a small child. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + 2 + 3 + ... + 999 + 1000 \\= (1 + 1000) + (2 + 999) + ... + (500 + 501) \\
= 500\times 1001"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Do you know this pattern?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of integers from 1 to 10 is 55"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of integers from 1 to 100 is 5050"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of integers from 1 to 1000 is 500500"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of integers from 1 to 10000 is 50005000 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus the sum of integers from 1 to 10^n is ever (10^n)/2 wrote 2 times together!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
